verses.text: Three days after Festus arrived in the province, he went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Festus succeeded Felix as governor and promptly made a political trip to Jerusalem to address ongoing concerns, showing the importance of Jerusalem in Jewish governance.

verses.text: The chief priests and the Jewish leaders presented their charges against Paul to Festus, urging him
verses.comment: The leaders quickly move against Paul, showing their persistent opposition to his proclamation of Christ and the tension between the nascent Church and traditional religious authorities.

verses.text: Asking a favor against Paul, that Festus would summon him to Jerusalem; for they planned to ambush him and kill him along the way.
verses.comment: The persistence of Paul’s enemies highlights the danger and hostility faced by early Christians spreading the Gospel, as foretold in Jesus’ own words (John 16:2).

verses.text: But Festus answered that Paul was being kept at Caesarea, and that he would soon go there himself.
verses.comment: Festus shows procedural neutrality, keeping Paul secure and demonstrating the Roman commitment to due process, a recurring theme in Acts.

verses.text: "Therefore," he said, "let your leaders come down with me, and if there is anything wrong with the man, let them bring charges against him."
verses.comment: Roman law required a formal accusation; Paul’s rights are protected, reflecting the providential use of secular authority for the Church’s protection.

verses.text: After Festus stayed among them no more than eight or ten days, he went down to Caesarea. The next day, he took his seat on the tribunal and ordered Paul to be brought to him.
verses.comment: Festus’ prompt action shows the seriousness of the charges and the careful judicial process that will ultimately serve to spread Paul's testimony to higher authorities.

verses.text: When Paul arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem surrounded him, bringing many serious charges against him, which they were unable to prove.
verses.comment: Paul’s innocence is highlighted; his accusers cannot substantiate their claims, echoing Christ’s own unjust trial (Luke 23:4).

verses.text: Paul said in his defense, "I have done nothing wrong against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar."
verses.comment: Paul insists on his innocence, respecting both religious and civil law—demonstrating a proper relationship between faith and government.

verses.text: But Festus, wanting to do the Jews a favor, asked Paul, "Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem and be tried there about these matters before me?"
verses.comment: Festus seeks political compromise, yet is careful to retain control over the trial, again preserving Paul from harm and allowing due opportunity for apostolic witness.

verses.text: But Paul replied, "I am standing before Caesar’s tribunal, where I ought to be tried. I have not wronged the Jews, as you yourself know very well."
verses.comment: Paul appeals to the principle of Roman justice and location, asserting his rights as a Roman citizen, a pivotal detail for his later appeal to Caesar.

verses.text: "If I am guilty and have done anything deserving death, I do not refuse to die. But if there is nothing to these charges against me, no one has the right to hand me over to them. I appeal to Caesar!"
verses.comment: Paul’s appeal is a legal right of Roman citizens. His willingness to accept martyrdom if guilty foreshadows the tradition of martyr witness and faithfulness even to death (Rev. 2:10).

verses.text: Festus, after conferring with his council, declared, "You have appealed to Caesar; to Caesar you shall go!"
verses.comment: Paul’s destiny to witness in Rome is being providentially fulfilled, aligning with the purpose stated in (Acts 23:11).

verses.text: Several days later, King Agrippa and Bernice arrived at Caesarea to greet Festus.
verses.comment: Agrippa II was knowledgeable in Jewish customs and law, providing an opportunity for broader proclamation of the Gospel.

verses.text: While they were staying there for many days, Festus discussed Paul’s case with the king, saying, "There is a man left prisoner by Felix."
verses.comment: Festus seeks Agrippa’s expertise on religious matters, foreshadowing Paul’s extended witness.

verses.text: "When I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and elders brought charges against him, asking for a sentence of condemnation."
verses.comment: Echoes the similar climactic moment when Christ was wrongfully condemned (Matt. 26:59).

verses.text: "I answered them that it is not Roman custom to hand over anyone before he has faced his accusers and been allowed to defend himself against the charges."
verses.comment: Roman justice aligns with biblical principles of fair hearings (Deuteronomy 19:15).

verses.text: "So when they had gathered here, I did not delay; I convened the court the next day and ordered the man to be brought."
verses.comment: Festus acts promptly, underlining the urgency and visibility of Paul’s case.

verses.text: "When his accusers stood up, they did not charge him with any of the crimes I expected."
verses.comment: Festus notes the unusual religious nature of the charges, rather than criminal or political offenses against Rome.

verses.text: "Instead, they had disputes with him about their own religion and about a certain Jesus, who had died, but whom Paul claims is alive."
verses.comment: Central importance of the Resurrection—the foundational event for the Church, prefigured in (Psalm 16:10) and fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: "Since I was uncertain about these questions, I asked whether he was willing to go to Jerusalem and be tried there regarding these matters."
verses.comment: Festus' uncertainty shows the mystery and complexity of the Christian faith to outsiders; the unique claims surrounding Jesus demand deeper investigation (John 7:46).

verses.text: "But when Paul appealed for his case to be reserved for the Emperor’s decision, I ordered him to be held until I send him to Caesar."
verses.comment: Paul’s journey to Rome—the heart of the Empire—will implicitly signify the spread of the Church’s witness and the universality of Christ’s message (Psalm 2:8).

verses.text: Then Agrippa said to Festus, "I would also like to hear the man myself." "Tomorrow," Festus replied, "you will hear him."
verses.comment: The Lord opens yet another door for Paul’s testimony before one well-versed in Jewish tradition, fulfilling Jesus’ prophecy that his followers would testify before kings (Matt. 10:18).

verses.text: So the next day Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp and entered the hall with the commanders and the leading men of the city. At Festus’s command, Paul was brought in.
verses.comment: The public nature of Paul’s audience recalls previous moments of the Church's witness before rulers (Acts 4:7), indicating the dignity and seriousness with which the faith is presented.

verses.text: Festus said, "King Agrippa, and all who are present with us, you see this man about whom the whole Jewish community has petitioned me, both in Jerusalem and here, shouting that he should not live any longer."
verses.comment: Paul’s controversy emphasizes the radical nature of Christ’s message, which demands a response and often brings division (Luke 12:51).

verses.text: "But I found that he had done nothing deserving death. And since he himself appealed to the Emperor, I have decided to send him."
verses.comment: Festus again asserts Paul’s innocence under the law, paralleling Pilate’s finding regarding Jesus (Luke 23:4).

verses.text: "But I have nothing definite to write to our lord about him. Therefore I have brought him before all of you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that after this examination I may have something to write."
verses.comment: Festus is seeking clarity on the charges to present to Caesar, underscoring the deep distinctions between Christian teaching and ordinary civil affairs.

verses.text: "For it seems unreasonable to send a prisoner without specifying the accusations against him."
verses.comment: Festus’ conclusion highlights the justice and transparency needed when bringing charges—an ethical principle rooted in scriptural tradition (Proverbs 18:17), and underlining the importance of truth in proclamation.
